2: "Do you still want to argue with me, the Almighty One?\q2 Since you criticize me, you should be able to answer my questions!"
4:
"Now I realize that I am completely worthless. So how could I answer those questions?\q2 I will put my hand over my mouth and not say anything.
\q1
5: I have already said more than I should have said,\q2 so now I will say nothing more."
6: Then Yahweh again spoke to Job from inside a powerful storm. He said,\q1
7:
"I want to ask you some questions,\q2 so act like a man and
\q2 get ready to answer my questions.

\q1
8:
Are you going to accuse me and say that I am unjust?\q2 Are you going to say that what I have done is wrong, in order that you can say that what you have done is right?
\q1
9:
Do you have the same amount of power as I do?\q2 Can your voice sound as loud as thunder, as mine can?


\q1
10:
If you can do that, then put on the robes\q2 that show that you are glorious and are greatly honored!
\q1
11:
Show that you are very angry;\q2 show that you have the right to humble people who are very proud!


\q1
12:
Humble those proud people just by looking at them angrily!\q2 Crush wicked people quickly!
\q1
13:
Bury them in the ground!\q2 Send them to the place where dead people are,
\q2 where they will not be able to get out!
\q1
14:
If you do that, I will congratulate you\q2 and say that truly you can save yourself by your own ability.


\q1
15:
Think also about hippopotamuses.\q2 I made you, and I made them also.
\q2 They eat grass, like oxen do.
\q1
16:
Their legs are very strong,\q2 and the muscles of their bellies are very powerful.


\q1
17:
Their tails are stiff like the branches of a cedar tree.\q2 The muscles of their thighs are close together.
\q1
18:
Their thigh bones are like tubes made of bronze,\q2 and the bones of their legs are like bars made of iron.


\q1
19:
Hippopotamuses are among the strongest of the animals that I made,\q2 and I, who created them, am the only one who can kill them.
\q1
20:
On the hills grows food for them to eat\q2 while many other wild animals play nearby.
\q1
21:
They lie down in the water under the lotus plants;\q2 they hide in tall reeds in the swamps.


\q1
22:
The hippopotamuses find shade under the lotus plants,\q2 and they are surrounded by willow trees growing in the streams.
\q1
23:
They are not disturbed by raging, flooding rivers;\q2 they are not even disturbed when rivers like the Jordan River rush over them.
\q1
24: No one can catch them with hooks\q2 or by piercing their noses with the teeth of a trap!
